article_title: New biotech incubator gives fledgling companies a boost
article_text:
New biotech incubator gives fledgling companies a boost Medical entrepreneurship can be 'cool and hip and sexy,' center's leader says

Photo: Marie D. De Jesus, Staff Raffaella Soldi director of biology of Beta Cat Pharmaceuticals...

In the world of biomedical research, some of the most rarefied brainpower can spend years pondering the single question of "What if?" Yet it is often the question that follows a discovery that can prove just as elusive: "What now?"

article_metadata.description: To help scientists move a eureka moment into the marketplace, Johnson & Johnson, one of the world's largest and most recognizable companies, has partnered with the Texas Medical Center to open a state-of-the-art business incubator near the medical campus.  JLABS @ TMC, unveiled this month, is a 34,000-square-foot urbane space with racks of crisp white lab coats and a maze of polished hallways leading to conference areas and dozens of labs stocked with the kind of cutting-edge equipment most startup companies can only dream of owning.  Twenty-two startup companies, including four international ones, were selected to be part of the inaugural group in Houston, ranging from a startup that developed a way to sort trillions of bio-molecules for diagnostic analysis, to one that hopes patient noncompliance can be tackled with a specialized phone call.  Graham Randall, who holds both a Ph.D. in molecular bio-physics and an MBA, is president and CEO of Noninvasix, a Houston company developing a technology to more easily monitor the oxygenation level in babies' brains during labor and delivery.  While his first experience opened doors, especially those at Texas Children's Hospital, for his fledgling company, he sees JLABS @ TMC as the next logical step.  Richter says when Johnson & Johnson Innovation was looking for a new location for a business incubator, its gaze settled on Houston, in large part because of the Texas Medical Center, with its combined patient population in the millions.  Randy Goodall, CEO of Austin-based NanoMedical Systems, migrated to medical technology from the semiconductor industry, which he feared was stagnating.  Barry Beverly, the CEO and co-founder of Innovate Wireless Health, hatched the idea to better reach those who might be skipping medication or not following doctor's orders by developing a reminder phone program.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam

og.description: To help scientists move a eureka moment into the marketplace, Johnson & Johnson, one of the world's largest and most recognizable companies, has partnered with the Texas Medical Center to open a state-of-the-art business incubator near the medical campus.  JLABS @ TMC, unveiled this month, is a 34,000-square-foot urbane space with racks of crisp white lab coats and a maze of polished hallways leading to conference areas and dozens of labs stocked with the kind of cutting-edge equipment most startup companies can only dream of owning.  Twenty-two startup companies, including four international ones, were selected to be part of the inaugural group in Houston, ranging from a startup that developed a way to sort trillions of bio-molecules for diagnostic analysis, to one that hopes patient noncompliance can be tackled with a specialized phone call.  Graham Randall, who holds both a Ph.D. in molecular bio-physics and an MBA, is president and CEO of Noninvasix, a Houston company developing a technology to more easily monitor the oxygenation level in babies' brains during labor and delivery.  While his first experience opened doors, especially those at Texas Children's Hospital, for his fledgling company, he sees JLABS @ TMC as the next logical step.  Richter says when Johnson & Johnson Innovation was looking for a new location for a business incubator, its gaze settled on Houston, in large part because of the Texas Medical Center, with its combined patient population in the millions.  Randy Goodall, CEO of Austin-based NanoMedical Systems, migrated to medical technology from the semiconductor industry, which he feared was stagnating.  Barry Beverly, the CEO and co-founder of Innovate Wireless Health, hatched the idea to better reach those who might be skipping medication or not following doctor's orders by developing a reminder phone program.
